arguments.argument: Political ads spread misinformation and manipulate public opinion.
Social media platforms lack transparency in political ad funding.
Foreign entities can exploit online ads to influence elections.
Banning political ads would reduce polarization and echo chambers.
Political ads often use microtargeting to manipulate voters.
Social media companies fail to effectively fact-check political ads.
It would level the playing field for candidates with fewer resources.
The spread of fake news is worsened by unregulated political ads.
Users should not be bombarded with biased political propaganda.
Social media should prioritize unbiased information over paid influence.
Political ads are a form of free speech protected under the First Amendment.
Banning them would disproportionately harm lesser-known candidates.
Social media is an essential tool for modern political campaigns.
Voters have the right to access political messages from various sources.
A ban would favor traditional media, which also runs political ads.
Regulation, not a ban, is a better solution to curb misinformation.
Political engagement on social media increases voter participation.
A ban would make it harder for grassroots movements to gain traction.
Transparency tools can ensure accountability in online political ads.
Social media platforms should not control political discourse through bans.
